thread.title: Province gave school boards $4.6 million to bargain
thread.title_full: Province gave school boards $4.6 million to bargain | Toronto Star

author: Kristin Rushowy
title: Province gave school boards $4.6 million to bargain
text:
Photos View photos zoom The province gave school boards almost $4.6 million to help cover the costs of bargaining under new legislation, on top of the controversial $2.5 million it has paid to three teacher unions.
A memo from the education ministry to Ontario school boards says the money will be divvied up among the boards for 2015-16 to help pay for negotiations created with its new, two-tier system.
At Queen’s Park on Monday, the Liberal government continued to face heavy criticism over the millions paid to education unions, no receipts required , to offset the costs of negotiations.
“You did it, too,” Education Minister Liz Sandals lectured the opposition Progressive Conservatives, reminding them they covered some negotiating expenses while in office.
“There’s always a cost to negotiations,” noted Premier Kathleen Wynne.
Progressive Conservative Leader Patrick Brown joked about the Liberals’ suggesting the funds went to pay for pizza and other meals.
“The pepperoni must be gold-plated,” said Brown.
“What was this money really for?” he asked, referring to the fact education unions have bankrolled election attack ads against the Tories to help the Liberals in every campaign since 2003.
The money given to the school boards’ associations in particular is to cover staffing required for central negotiations — where big items like salary and class size are hammered out — as well as travel and accommodation, and legal help, says the memo, which was obtained by the Star.
Last week, it was revealed that the Ontario government has paid $2.5 million in total to the Ontario Secondary School Teachers’ Federation, the Ontario English Catholic Teachers’ Association as well as AEFO, which represents French-board teachers, for this round of bargaining.
The Elementary Teachers’ Federation of Ontario, the only teacher union without a signed agreement, has said it won’t accept such money and has not in the past.
The government on Friday released figures showing it had also given $1.2 million-plus to the teacher unions — with the exception of ETFO — in the last two rounds of bargaining.
In 2008, $690,000 was paid to unions representing high school teachers (OSSTF), French-board teachers (AEFO) as well as support staff (CUPE).
In 2012, $200,000 went to OSSTF, $170,000 to the French-board teachers and $181,000 to CUPE.
Ann Hawkins, president of the Catholic teachers’ union, told the Star the new bargaining system was “incredibly time- and cost-heavy,” so the extra funds were needed.
Sandals has said “this has been an unusually dragged out process,” because “each and every clause” in contracts had to be renegotiated.
“Both the unions and the boards have had extraordinary costs because everybody is having to rent space and find venues and rooms,” she added. “This will never happen again. This is the end of the transformation . . . I think of it as investing in transforming a system that didn’t work.”
An email from Sandals released late Friday afternoon said this kind of expense has been in place since 2008. Since then, $3.741 million has been paid out to teacher unions.
On Monday, Sandals emphasized the changes to the bargaining process mean the payouts will not be needed in the future.
“We will never, ever have to fund the unions again because the transformation will be done,” Sandals told reporters.
